newsitem.title: GERMANY: Camels pass through Brandenburg Gate.
newsitem.headline: Camels pass through Brandenburg Gate.

text.p: A caravan of 11 camels from Abu Dhabi loped through Berlin's landmark Brandenburg Gate on Thursday, following in the footsteps of previous Berlin guests Bill Clinton, Pope John Paul II and Nelson Mandela.

In a publicity stunt to promote Europe's first ever camel races on Sunday, Germans and Arabs in flowing white robes and traditional cloth headdresses led the double-humped beasts through the gate, symbol of German unification.

Some 30,000 people are expected to attend the tournament of six camel races organised under the patronage of United Arab Emirates President Zayed bin Sultan al Nahayan and the German camel-racing club Fatamorgana.

The event is aimed at improving cultural and commercial ties between the two countries, but German animal-lovers have called for a boycott of the races, arguing camels are not suited to northern European terrain or climate.

"Camels may be a little strange for Berlin," Emirates Interior Minister Khalfan Khamis told journalists. "But sport is an important part of our culture and I hope we can use it to build a bridge for greater cooperation between our peoples."
